title: Ticket #6321: condor_annex status
description:
Miron feels that condor_annex status is less confusing than condor_status -annex, so we should certainly implement the former and possibly remove the latter. We've also agreed that the unit of interest in annexes is the instance, so the default format should report on that basis. So far, so easy a pass-through (just add -annex -compact, or -const ... -compact, since condor_status just ANDs together multiple -const flags).

However, the current condor_annex -status also reports on instances in the annex but not in the pool; this is valuable and should not be lost. So we have to decide how to include this information in the output.
remarks:
2017-Jun-27 16:42:50 by tlmiller:
The first implementation should probably just invoke condor_status and pass the appropriate arguments through (including most of condor_annex 's). The missing instances summary should probably be printed at the bottom, so we'd have to fork() rather than exec(). Once condor_status was done, condor_annex would contact EC2 to get the full list of annex instances, and then (have to) contact the collector a second time to get the list of instances in the pool to find the difference (since it couldn't depend on the output format).

One way to avoid making the second collector query would be to enforce the condor_status output format, so that condor_annex could parse it (before printing it out). This would require people who want better formatting control to use condor_status for that and then call condor_annex for the missing instances summary; even an option to suppress the per-instance data would be still result in two queries being made, so this is distinctly suboptimal.

Discussion with TJ revealed four other options:

  1. Call condor_status and get a fixed format output on standard error, but the usual output on standard out; condor_annex could then parse the standard error, instead. The fixed format could be a compile-time constant, or supplied on the command line (before the other options); in either case, once set, those options would have to be immutable by further command-line options. Probably not useful for anyone else.

  2. As above, except that the fixed format is printed on standard out, separated from the usual output with a well-known (or given) separator. This would probably be a little easier to program in condor_annex, but not any more useful.

  3. Pass the data from EC2 about an annex's instances to condor_status via stdin and use a custom summary/footer format function (the ability to specify such does not presently exist) to read from it, compute the difference, and print the summary. Extremely specific to condor_annex, except, potentially, the part about specifying custom footers.

  4. Extend condor_status with a 'merge' mode: accept ads on standard in, and from the query, and a join condition. Print three differently-formatted outputs: those ads which were in both the "left" and "right" sets of ads; those ads only from standard in, and those ads only from the query. (Be sure to allow for the null format, which prints nothing.) This would be of general interest and use. condor_annex would synthesize ads for instances it found and feed them to condor_status 's standard in, specifying the join condition as the AnnexName attribute.

2017-Jun-28 14:16:01 by tlmiller:
A use case for point 4:

A user reported (to GregT and/or TJ) that some accounting ads were missing from the list in the collector. These ads, were, however, available directly from the negotiator, so something like 

$ condor_user_prio -negotiator | condor_status -any -const 'MyType == "Accounting"' -merge:left-only

would have been handy to have (where the default join condition would have to be on the Name attribute).

2017-Jul-03 14:49:57 by tlmiller:
Since 'condor_annex status' should report on instances that aren't currently in the pool, we need some way to identify those instances. That is, #6313's third point is actually relevant.

While I'm OK with telling the user not to use an annex name as a client token prefix (that is, ignoring the possibility of mistaken identity when dealing with a name annex), I'm less happy about pulling in any instance (or spot fleet request) which matches the pattern <name>_<guid>, since it seems a pretty obvious one to use.

Luckily, all instances can be tagged (max of 50 tags), and since AWS reserves the 'aws:' key prefix for itself, it makes sense to say that our users shouldn't tag things with 'htcondor:AnnexName', and use that, instead.

Unluckily, while we can tag at creation time for on-demand instances, we can't yet do so via a spot fleet request. However, we have reason to believe that this feature will be forthcoming, probably later this year. So for now, only report on-demand instances that are missing from the collector (and note that the report doesn't include spot instances).

2017-Aug-16 19:31:49 by tlmiller:
Don't forget to update clouds/aws.tex when this work is done to reflect the change to using on-creation tags for both on-demand and SFR instances.

Also, don't forget to remove the mention of the v8.7.3 bug w.r.t. SFR instances and condor_annex -status without an annex name when creating the v8.7.4 Wiki pages.

2017-Aug-28 15:33:14 by tlmiller: 
$ condor_user_prio -negotiator -l -modular | condor_status -any -const 'MyType == "Accounting"' -merge
The following ads were found in both the left and right -hand ads:
MyType             TargetType         Name

Accounting         none               <none>

The following ads were found only in the left-hand ads:
MyType             TargetType         Name

None               None               tlmiller@azaphrael.org

2017-Aug-29 15:58:40 by tlmiller:
Future work: add a flag so condor_status only outputs left, right, or both. While a -left-summary flag for condor_status would be interesting and perhaps welcome for condor_annex status, for now I think we need to to include all of the instance IDs in the output, which we can't do in condor_status without generic aggregation operators.

2017-Aug-29 16:02:54 by tlmiller:
Documentation note: say something along the lines of

"AnnexInstance ads aren't real Machine ads, so some options you may know from condor_status will behave unexpectedly. The following options are known to work, although they don't change the presentation of the missing instances: -af, -compact, -json, and -xml."

Consider checking other, more-useful, options from the list in condor_status -help.

2017-Sep-04 18:00:40 by tlmiller:
As TJ points out, condor_status -merge should take a file argument so that we don't break things when we change it later.

2017-Oct-25 16:30:54 by tim:
Doc review: Looks good.

2017-Jul-05 17:13   Check-in [51841]: (#6321) Pass 'condor_annex status' through to 'condor_status -annex -compact'. Update 'condor_annex -status' to permit operation without an annex name, using tags (on-demand instances only until a new AWS feature arrives). Add new output format (summary) for 'condor_annex -status' w/o an annex name prepatory [...] (By Todd L Miller )
creator: tlmiller
